text: Gallic acid is an organic compound with the chemical formula or . The systematic name of gallic acid is 3,4,5-trihydroxybenzoic acid. Salts and esters of gallic acid are called gallates. It has no relation to gallium. == Name == Gallic acid is named after plant galls, which contain gallic acid and tannins, which also often contain gallic acid and its esters. "Gallic acid" would be the systematic name of gallium(III) hydroxide, if it were treated as an oxoacid of gallium. Like its structural analog aluminium hydroxide ("aluminic acid"), this compound is amphoteric and is usually named as a metal hydroxide rather than an oxoacid. Salts of the anion are also called "gallates". == References == Category:Carboxylic acids Category:Aromatic compounds
title: Gallic acid
